data.title: Show inactive 'gear' icon in Debug when launch.json is not present
data.body:
I found two SO questions ([1](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42979405/visual-studio-code-debug-menu-bar-gear-icon-missing/43013118#43013118), [2](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/43012391/visual-studio-code-debug-not-showing-gear/43012944#43012944)) tagged with vscode, asking where to find the "gear" icon for editing `launch.json`.  These were both asked within the last day, but I don't know how often this happens otherwise.

At least one of these people have been following a guide, and so the root cause fix would reasonably be "update the guide to better reflect VS Code", but I think a good improvement might be to have the gear icon there any ways, and add some visual styling to show it's not usable yet, like a dithered grey. 

On second thought that may be difficult to express with vscode's default color scheme. Maybe have the gear always drawn, and if the `tasks.json` doesn't exist, create one (basically the same behavior as the play button when `tasks.json` isn't present).

data.title: Show icons on Open Editors pane (bar) when collapsed

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open some editors
2. Collapse the Open Editors pane in the Explorer

I really like that the collapsed bar shows how many unsaved files there are, but unfortunately it removes the command icons Horizontal Editor Group Layout, Save All, and Close All Editors.

Also, it would be nice if `"explorer.openEditors.visible": 0` did not hide the pane. Another option, such as `"explorer.openEditors.visible": false` could handle that. I don't like the pane itself, but when collapsed the bar still has value by showing how many editors are unsaved (and could have more value if the icons didn't disappear).

data.title: Can't use "open loaded scripts" to load a URL with query params
data.body: Chrome-debug supports .js files with query parameters (`http://localhost/foo.js?bar`). But if I load one with "Open loaded scripts", the query parameter is stripped. This happens here: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/debug/browser/debugContentProvider.ts#L40 since fsPath doesn't include the query parameter. Any idea how to make this work? I don't think URI is expecting to have a URL with another scheme.

data.title: Windows Error Reporting disabled?

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

I'm doing extension development and am currently hitting an issue that only repros when I build my extension in Release mode and don't have a debugger attached.  I would like for Windows Error Reporting to catch my crash and save out a crash dump so I can investigate it offline.  I have the registry set up to save crash dumps under c:\Windows, but nothing ever gets saved there.

Is VS Code somehow disabling crash reports and crash dump saving?  Is there a way to turn this off so I can find the source of my crash?

Thanks!

data.title: Undo History & The Journal of Irreproducible Results
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: MacOS Sierra

Steps to Reproduce:

Haha. No way. I tried. It's completely random. Crazy making.

Here is the deal:

I looked at a couple open issues about Undo History in this repo. You guys assert that the history is infinite unless the file is written to by another process. My experience conflicts with that. On several very frustrating occasions, I lose all Undo history right after I save. I do have a process that watches the file and updates the build after each save but that process does not modify the file itself, at least not in any way that I can tell visually or content wise. But even if it turns out to be some crazy thing on my end (maybe one of the tools opens and saves the file as is instead of just reading from it) the fact that an editor loses its Undo history is enough for me and most developers (trust me, when enough run into this) to dump this otherwise great piece of software.

Would you consider being a normal editor like Sublime et al and preserve the Undo history in the same way those editors do? I've never had a single complaint in my whole adult life about something as trivial as this.

Please fix (something, not me)

data.title: Provide API to access breakpoints before debugging

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 Anniversary

In the latest update of the PowerShell extension (0.11.0) we now use an integrated terminal that hosts the editing and debugging session.  One thing that we're missing now is the ability to be aware of breakpoint set in .ps1 files before the debugger is started.  Here's a scenario:

1. The user opens up a new VS Code session with the PowerShell extension installed
2. The user opens a .ps1 file for editing and the "PowerShell Integrated Console" opens
3. The user adds breakpoints in the editor pane for the script file by clicking in the gutter
4. The user runs the script in the Integrated Console by typing out its path and pressing enter.
5. The script runs but none of the breakpoints are set.
6. The user is confused, now presses F5 to debug the script.  The breakpoints are sent to the debug adapter which registers them in the session and then runs the script
7. The breakpoints are now hit and the debugger UI stops correctly

Ideally there'd be some event I could subscribe to and be notified when breakpoints are added to or removed from an open file when debugging isn't active.  This would allow me to send that information to my language service to be prepared for the user to execute the script outside of the debugger.

If there's another way you've thought of to make this work, I'd be very happy to hear it.  Having this capability would go a long way to reduce user confusion when debugging PowerShell scripts interactively.

Thanks!

/cc @isidorn @weinand

data.title: [Test] typescript.tsserver.log
data.body:
Test Plan For #22915

**OS**
- [x] Linux - @mousetraps 
- [x] OSX - @jrieken 
- [x] Window - @waderyan 

Check to see that the `typescript.tsserver.log` works as expected.

1. Open a small js/ts project

2. Run the `Open TS server log file` command

    **Expected**: This should show an alert about logging not being enabled.

3. Click to enable logging and reload VSCode.

     **Expected**: This should reload VSCode and create a new setting `"typescript.tsserver.log": "verbose",`

4. After code reloads, open a js/ts file again and run `Open TS server log file`

     **Expected**: This should open a log file in the editor. Perform some edits on the js/ts file and see that the logs is updated

5. Right click on the log file tab and try going to the folder location.

    **Expected**: This should reveal the folder location in the explorer. There should be a `tsserver.log` file, possible along with with `ti-*` files for typings installation

data.title: Unfocused Tab Is Same Color as Focused Extension Tab Header (With No Tab Border) - Many Themes Affected
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Win 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VS Code with the Welcome tab open
2. Open one of the extension's tabs by clicking on an extension
3. Select Dark (Visual Studio) theme (as an example) - many other themes have this problem too
4, The extension's header has the same color as the non-focused tab (with no borders either)
5. Switch between the tabs - which tab do you think you are on? It makes me think I am on the Welcome tab and clicking the different colored Extension tab does nothing (because I'm already on that tab).
6. An example of where this confusion does not occur is the the High Contrast theme (because there are borders on the tab and tab with focus gets outlined with a different color) or Red theme (because the header is appropriately not the same color as the unfocused tab).

I can provide screenshots if necessary for clarification.

data.title: Proposed Terminal API onData
data.body:
Fixes #23177 

---

**API**

```ts
export interface Terminal {
	/**
	 * Experimental API that allows listening to the raw data stream coming from the terminal's
	 * pty process (including ANSI escape sequences).
	 *
	 * @param callback The callback that is triggered when data is sent to the terminal.
	 */
	onData(callback: (data: string) => any): void;
}
```

**Usage**

```ts
const terminal = vscode.window.createTerminal();
terminal.onData(data => console.log(data));
```

Results in something like this:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/24314062/f189f1ac-109c-11e7-8f90-daa191d99c57.png)

If we wanted to ship this it might make more sense to strip escape sequences before firing the `onData` callback. In the meantime use something like [`Strings.removeAnsiEscapeCodes`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/08b14f723067b729ab4b952c30cdc976242e2100/src/vs/base/common/strings.ts#L626) or [`TerminalDecoder`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/08b14f723067b729ab4b952c30cdc976242e2100/src/vs/workbench/parts/tasks/electron-browser/terminalTaskSystem.ts#L39) to strip them.

**Notes**

- Only one `onData` callback can be registered at once, called it again will override the old one.
- Only when `onData` is called will the terminal send the data stream over IPC.

Create a typescript file, and import one of the modules. Current behavior: VS Code intellisense shows duplicate entries while showing intellisense Expected behavior: Avoid duplicate entries while showing intellisense. (Note: This issue does not happen if @types packages isn't installed)

data.title: Investigate exposing ITerminalInstance.onData as a propose API
VS Code Will Not Update
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

VS Code doesn't update.  When I start it, it tells me that it will update the next time it restarts.  I click "Update Now" or click "Later" and close it on my own and it closes but does not ever restart.  When I start it again manually I get the update message again.  I have tried disabling all plugins and still have the issue.

- VSCode Version: Version 1.9.1 (1.9.1)
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.3 (16D32)

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Open VS Code.
2.  Click "Update Now" when the update notification appears.
3.  Notice that VS Code closes but never reopens.
4.  Open VS Code again.
5.  Notice the update notification appears again.
6.  GOTO step 2.

I get this error on startup, but after disabling material icons and restarting it goes away but VS Code still won't update.:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22749332/24311325/048da57a-10aa-11e7-8f7c-0fcf50eb911f.png)

I have these extensions installed:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22749332/24311359/306a9b9e-10aa-11e7-972f-e8e81459dbd0.png)

data.title: Undo of multiple deletes causes incorrect TextDocumentChangeEvents
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2 and HEAD (ba8799194d1a5e85f91418721ee295670e5d22b9)
- OS Version: 10.12.3

My setup:
1. Create an extension that listens to `onDidChangeTextDocument`.
```
public onDidChangeTextDocument(ev: vscode.TextDocumentChangeEvent): void {
	console.log(JSON.stringify(ev.contentChanges));
}
```
2. Start debugging that extension in vscode.

How to reproduce.
1. Create a document with the contents "abc\n"
2. Place your cursor after "c" (before the "\n")
3. Press delete key once. Wait for a second.
```
[{"range":[{"line":0,"character":2},{"line":0,"character":3}],"rangeLength":1,"text":""}]
```
4. Press delete key again. Wait for a second.
```
[{"range":[{"line":0,"character":1},{"line":0,"character":2}],"rangeLength":1,"text":""}]
```
5. The document state is now "a\n".
6. Perform undo command (cmd+z). You editor should return to state "abc\n" (as expected). If it doesn't you probably have an extension installed (e.g. vim) that is preventing this behavior. For the purpose of reproducing this bug, make sure you don't have an extension like this installed.
```
[
{"range":[{"line":0,"character":1},{"line":0,"character":1}],"rangeLength":0,"text":"b"},
{"range":[{"line":0,"character":2},{"line":0,"character":2}],"rangeLength":0,"text":"c"}
]
```

According to https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/23136#issuecomment-289083305, I should be able to apply the changes from step 6 "at once" on the document state from step 5. Doing so would result in the final document of "ab\nc", which is incorrect.
